name: Elusive Truths
description: The practiced mind is adept at manipulating perception. Which movements are sincere, and which are feints? Behind one door waits the truth; behind the other, a grizzly end.

name: Icy Shell Game v1.3b
description:
My version of Icy Shell Game v1.3 by Ajar. I cut the Sweeps Weeks in favor of Ice Wall and Trick Of Light combo. The RSVP is also included to make Hokusais and Fetals more threatening. Jackson Howards are good, open up some Archive kills.

The only concern now is without Sweeps Weeks the deck might struggle with economy, especially from Account Siphons. Jinteki players please feel free to test it !

name: Jinteki JBC
BGB Deck
Icy Shell Game v1.3c
Dino is a hacker
Baby's first NBN Growing up
description:
17/02/2014

Since last version, received new cards so here's the changes :

  • Removed 1 Corporate War

  • Added 1 AstroScript Pilot Program

  • Removed 1 Dedicated Response Team

  • Removed 2 Ghost Branch
  • Removed 2 Marked Accounts
  • Removed 2 Private Contracts

  • Removed 1 PAD Campaign

  • Added 1 SanSan City Grid

  • Added 2 Bernice Mai

  • Added 3 Green Level Clearance

  • Added 2 Shipment from SanSan

Basically, going from a more Asset based economy to an Operation based one, so it is less vulnerable to trashing and less click intensive (Marked Accounts & Private Contracts both require clicks).

Also replaced the Ghost Branchs (a bit unreliable) with Bernice Mai, which can give the doubt were as the upgrades could be that or SanSan.

For Agendas, + 1 AstroScript (it is really good), but no Character Assassination, as I figure that the runner would get tagged at some point anyway.

At this point, I still need to check if I could use Jackson Howards, if I still keep the Midseason Replacements + Psychographics around (Psychographics is amazing against the Tag Me runners I see in my meta), to see if Shipment from SanSan is really reliable, and to lastly maybe revise the ICE a bit.

name: Whizzard does Oldschool v1.1
description: Money and Breakers. Pure as heaven, efficient as hell. Try to get to late game fast! - v1.0: Start - v1.1: Reconfiguration after input from Sebbes and Darkpact. Made 12/22 at the Strassbourg Store Championship on 16.02.14

name: Gabriel 1
description: Based on Gabriel's Gambit deck

name: Red Shift
description:
Reina Roja, Rook and Xanadu will make the corp think twice about rezzing their ICE.

Use Knights to neutralize big ICE and to facecheck ICE. Use Rooks to (duh) waste the corp's credits. Bishops (and Ice Carver) reduce big ICE to where static ICEbreakers can deal with them and/or save you credits on big barriers.

Starting hands worth keeping include Knight and some form of economy or Kati Jones and a Diesel.

name: Criminal Andromeda Oldscul
Noise 1
Red Denial v2.0
description:
I wasn't entirely satisfied with the previous versions of this Red Denial deck, so I decided to change a lot of things. I don't believe you always need multiple access (Medium / Nerve Agent or the HQ / R&D Interfaces), especially not when you're dominating the game.

This deck uses 4 MU for IBs + a Datasucker, and 3 MU granted by Deep Red for the Cäissa programs (ideally 2 Knight and 1 Rook in mid / late game).

There's also plenty of economy, to allow you to repeatedly trash things like SanSan (even if re-installed by Interns), and to defend yourself against tag n bag traces. Compromised Employee is there for the same reasons, plus it's always a good thing to have a passive mean of income that might happen during a Run.

It's a rather simple deck, but does one thing definitely well: allows you to run wherever you want, and often for a cheap price too, considering how much a rez will cost to the Corp (and the extra credits you might earn from it).

name: yea
The Right Tool for the Job v1.3
description:
I always liked Deus Ex, and usually have a couple copies in my Shaper decks. Sharpshooter is possibly even better, so I just had to build a deck around those two.

With 3 copies of Self-modifying Code and Clone Chip, you should always be able to install one of them, on-the-fly or preparing for a Run. A couple Levy AR Lab Access allow you to simply never run out of options.

Since there's plenty of memory use with all these programs, I had to pick ZU.13 and Creeper. It's a good thing Sharpshooter can break many of those Sentry anyway, cause Creeper is quite expensive to use anyway. I also added a couple Dyson Mem Chip, just in case.

To protect from traces and tag n bag decks, since I didn't wanna have Plascrete Carapace in this deck too, I added 3 copies of Borrowed Satellite as well, bringing the maximum Link up to 6. It was only natural, then, to add Underworld Contact.

Lastly, Diesel and Freelance Coding Contract for an extra boost that might surprise your opponent. Same story goes for IMP, which can be quite handy to trash all those expensive upgrades or assets... a recurring SanSan, for example (gotta hate Interns!).

name: Bust 1.0
description:
The ideas is simple : harass the corp recklessly to make him rez ice, pump datasuckers up make a big Kate-shaped hole in R&D and bring a shovel.

Parasites should be installed when blocking ice are encountered on R&D (or interesting other servers) or when the corp's turn ends through Self-Modifying Code and Clone Chips, so they cost less and can be surged immediately, or to surprise-breake rezzed ice.

Money is pretty tight, as is keeping card advantage, so don't hesitate to draw through Professional Contact even if it means difficult decisions on what to keep.

name: Scoop! v1.0
description:
My take at 40 cards fast advance with The World is Yours*.

13 pieces of EtR ICE out of 15, with a couple dangerous options. RSVP to ideally prevent them from trashing SanSan, not that it's a big issue when Interns will take her back. It's also good as a stopper, anyway, just place it in front of some EtR ICE and they'll have to break it or jack out.

This deck imposes a very fast game to the Runner, and you should ideally score at least a couple Agenda before he can have a complete rig. If there's an AstroScript between them, you might have the victory in your hands already.

It takes a bit of a risk approach too, thought, because economy is quite frail as it is, even with mostly low cost ICE.

name: Dino is a hacker v2
description: Dont know if I need Same old Thing here, maybe Profesional Subcontract?

name: Kit - Dinosaurus
description: Advice welcome.

name: NEXT Design:Guarding the Net
description: Advice welcome. Considering replacing the Archers with Tollbooths due to the lack of cheap agendas to forfeit.

name: Reina - Caissa
description: Advice encouraged.

name: First Runner Deck
description: Started playing yesterday.

name: First Runner Deck (for Drew)
First Corp Deck
description: still a work in progress

name: Criminal?!
NEXT Flash Freeze - Cheat ICE v1.1
description:
Push out ICE early and aim to score a quick Vitruvius/ABT to force the runner to play by your rules.

This is a slower version of my previous deck. Whereas before the goal was to apply constant rapid pressure, this deck tries to push into the midgame as fast as possible and then hold it there, continuing to build ice fortresses and then open scoring windows when a runner has to deal with your Janus or Wotan.

Opening strategy:

Ideally you want to have some cheap ICE or one of your cheat operations (BER/Oversight) to dump out some ICE before your first turn. If you have limited options in terms of usable early ICE, prioritize likely targets depending on runner (HQ for Criminal and R&D for everyone else).

ICE Rationale:

A good mix of heavy and cheap ICE, though with the cheaters they're all essentially cheap. I used to think Howler was bad because runners can just jack out, but that can open opportunities for you to score. Many runners will run at you on their last click with so many clickable ICE.

I'm still clinging to the NEXT Bronzes since they're super cheap ETRs that force the runner to dig out their code breaker, though I might swap them out for something else. I'm really looking forward to more NEXT Ice being released.

Ice Wall is just sorta there. They can easily be replaced with Wall of Static/Paper Wall if influence is needed elsewhere.

Other Considerations:

Dumped out Ash. They can serve as additional bait early on, but with so many assets I don't think that's necessary. I'm also starting to see a lot of links out there. The key with this deck is to stop them at the Ice.

I still really like the idea of Biotic Labour for a quick advance, especially with the more solid econ, but I'm not sure what to exchange for it.

Thanks to temporar for their suggestions

name: You may have to sell one of your kidney
description: Inspired by db0's "Untrashable"

name: 2014 Portland: Guardian Games, Store Championship 1ST PLACE
description:
Pretty standard NBN Rush deck. Normally I like TMI, but they did nothing for me all day...so I would probably switch those. TMI is GREAT if you can get it in an opening hand, but kind of rough to pull off mid-late. RSVP would be good in this too, but then you get to a severe lack of actual run-stopping ICE.

Bernice is a good way to tax/slow down the runner & a good goal of this deck is to keep the runner poor/busy with other things as you get the Astro Train (Transformers anyone?!) moving. Sometimes, that even means letting them trash Jacksons too...so don't feel you always need to sac them. (depending on game state, obviously)

TGTBT is a great agenda to just throw out naked & sacrifice it if you can.

Went undefeated with this deck all day but a couple games could have definitely gone either way.

Runners faced at the tourney: Andromeda, Andromeda, Kit, Kate

Shout-Out to Riley for helping me tinker with stuff & Andrew/Ian/Rockwell for being much better NBN builders than myself.

name: 2014 Portland: Guardian Games, Store Championship 1ST PLACE
description:
Living life dangerously!

The key to this is making as many smart runs as possible & keeping the pressure on.

I like Knights...I like Parasites...let's try & run both!

MOST games I was happy to see Parasite more, but Knight can be incredibly handy in the right situation. Usually I was happy to see either come up.

I'd probably drop Forged for another Lawyer Up, but other than that I was real happy with this list.

Went undefeated all day.

Corps faced at the tourney: Weyland BaBW, HB eTF, Weyland BaBW, NBN TWiY

name: Edge of Weyland
description: You're Weyland, you have lots of cash. Use it to build up huge stacks of cheap ice and run interference where the runner doesn't have the right stuff to get through it, or to tax them later in the game. Ideally at some point you can get a project atlas off and search for and reveal another project atlas, jackson or a melange and try to pass off an edge of world in your one remote server as whatever you looked for. If the runner is one who will bite, their head explodes. If your secret is already out, you can play to the fear of edge of world and chain a second project atlas off the first putting you within striking distance of a grindy agenda point win.

name: Another Brick in The Wall
description: Only 7 agendas gives me more room for other stuff. Since 6 of them are 3-pointers, stealing one could be fatal from Punitive Counterstrike(s). If I can get a brain damage on the runner early, it will make the risk of Scorched Earth and Punitive Counterstrike even greater. Lost of money and big ice should give me a virtually impenetrable server, so I can score agendas at my leisure.

name: Marked for Stall
description:
Basically, the idea is to screw with the runner, then fast advance. If you can get Datapool out, you can just drain 4 credits a turn from the runner, or get a free tag. Closed Accounts, Freelancer, etc etc.

Due to a gentleman's agreement between friends, this deck has cards from the Core set and Genesis cycle only, with no Creation and Control. (So no, I won't swap the Tips for Jackson Howard)

Could turn into a tag n' bag, but I don't really like it. Economy is dodgy unless you can get at least one of the Adonises, or a Marked Accounts.

EDIT: Going to consider some Rototurrets - but am going to test first
